texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Back in 2011, I decided to try out a new method for hosting my websites and other applications:  colocation . Before that, I used shared hosting, VPS providers ("cloud" wasn't a popular thing back then), and dedicated servers. Each had their drawbacks in different areas. Some didn't perform well, some couldn't recover from failure well, and some were terribly time consuming to maintain.
texts.text: Back in 2011, I decided to try out a new method for hosting my websites and other applications:  colocation . Before that, I used shared hosting, VPS providers ("cloud" wasn't a popular thing back then), and dedicated servers. Each had their drawbacks in different areas. Some didn't perform well, some couldn't recover from failure well, and some were terribly time consuming to maintain.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This post will explain why I decided to try colocation and will hopefully help you avoid some of my mistakes.
texts.text: This post will explain why I decided to try colocation and will hopefully help you avoid some of my mistakes.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Why choose colocation?
texts.text: Why choose colocation?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: For the majority of us, hosting an application involves renting something from another company. This includes tangible things, such as disk space, servers, and networking, as well as the intangible items, like customer support. We all choose how much we rent (and hope our provider does well) and how much we do ourselves.
texts.text: For the majority of us, hosting an application involves renting something from another company. This includes tangible things, such as disk space, servers, and networking, as well as the intangible items, like customer support. We all choose how much we rent (and hope our provider does well) and how much we do ourselves.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Colocation usually involves renting space in a rack, electricity, and network bandwidth. In these environments, the customer is expected to maintain the server hardware, perimeter network devices (switches, routers, and firewalls), and all of the other equipment downstream from the provider's equipment. Providers generally offer good price points for these services since they only need to ensure your rack is secure, powered, and networked.
texts.text: Colocation usually involves renting space in a rack, electricity, and network bandwidth. In these environments, the customer is expected to maintain the server hardware, perimeter network devices (switches, routers, and firewalls), and all of the other equipment downstream from the provider's equipment. Providers generally offer good price points for these services since they only need to ensure your rack is secure, powered, and networked.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As an example, a quarter rack in Dallas at a low to mid-range colocation provider can cost between $200-400 per month. That normally comes with a power allotment (mine is 8 amps) and network bandwidth (more on that later). In my quarter rack, I have five 1U servers plus a managed switch. One of those servers acts as my firewall.

One of those servers acts as my firewall.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's consider a similar scenario at a dedicated hosting provider. I checked some clearance prices in Dallas while writing this post and found pricing for servers which have similar CPUs as my servers, but with much less storage. The pricing for five servers runs about $550/month and we haven't even considered a switch and firewall yet.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Step 1: Buy quality parts
texts.text: Step 1: Buy quality parts

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Seriously -  buy quality parts . That doesn't mean you need to go buy the newest server available from a well-known manufacturer, but you do need to find reliable parts in a new or used server.
texts.text: Seriously -  buy quality parts . That doesn't mean you need to go buy the newest server available from a well-known manufacturer, but you do need to find reliable parts in a new or used server.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I've built my environment entirely with  Supermicro  servers. The  X9SCi-LN4F  servers have been extremely reliable. My first two came brand new from  Silicon Mechanics  and I'm a big fan of their products. Look at their Rackform R.133 for something very similar to what I have.
texts.text: I've built my environment entirely with  Supermicro  servers. The  X9SCi-LN4F  servers have been extremely reliable. My first two came brand new from  Silicon Mechanics  and I'm a big fan of their products. Look at their Rackform R.133 for something very similar to what I have.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My last three have all come from  Mr. Rackables  (an eBay seller). They're used X9SCi-LN4F servers, but they're all in good condition. I couldn't beat the price for those servers, either.
texts.text: My last three have all come from  Mr. Rackables  (an eBay seller). They're used X9SCi-LN4F servers, but they're all in good condition. I couldn't beat the price for those servers, either.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Before you buy, do some reading on brand reliability and compatibility. If you plan to run Linux, do a Google search for the model of the server and the version of Linux you plan to run. Also, take a moment to poke around some forums to see what other people think of the server. Go to  WebHostingTalk  and search for hardware there, too.

Also, take a moment to poke around some forums to see what other people think of the server. Go to  WebHostingTalk  and search for hardware there, too.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Buying quality parts gives you a little extra piece of mind, especially if your colo is a long drive from your home or work.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Step 2: Ask questions
texts.text: Step 2: Ask questions

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Your first conversation with most providers will be through a salesperson. That's not necessarily a bad thing since they will give you a feature and pricing overview fairly quickly. However, I like to ask additional questions of the salesperson to learn more about the technical staff.
texts.text: Your first conversation with most providers will be through a salesperson. That's not necessarily a bad thing since they will give you a feature and pricing overview fairly quickly. However, I like to ask additional questions of the salesperson to learn more about the technical staff.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Step 3: Get specific on networking
texts.text: Step 3: Get specific on networking

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Look for cities with very diverse network options. Big cities, or cities with lots of datacenters, will usually have good network provider choices and better prices. In Texas, your best bet is Dallas (which is where I host).
texts.text: Look for cities with very diverse network options. Big cities, or cities with lots of datacenters, will usually have good network provider choices and better prices. In Texas, your best bet is Dallas (which is where I host).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I've learned that bandwidth measurement is one of the biggest areas of confusion and "creative interpretation" in colocation hosting. Every datacenter I've hosted with has handled things differently.
texts.text: I've learned that bandwidth measurement is one of the biggest areas of confusion and "creative interpretation" in colocation hosting. Every datacenter I've hosted with has handled things differently.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There are four main ways that most colocation providers handle networking:
texts.text: There are four main ways that most colocation providers handle networking:

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 95th percentile
texts.text: 95th percentile

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This is sometimes called  burstable billing  since it allows you to have traffic bursts without getting charged a lot for it. In the old days, you had to commit to a rate and stick with it (more on that method next). 95th percentile billing allows you to have some spikes during the measurement period without requiring negotiations for a higher transfer rate.
texts.text: This is sometimes called  burstable billing  since it allows you to have traffic bursts without getting charged a lot for it. In the old days, you had to commit to a rate and stick with it (more on that method next). 95th percentile billing allows you to have some spikes during the measurement period without requiring negotiations for a higher transfer rate.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Long story short, this billing method measures your bandwidth on regular intervals and throws out the top 5% of your intervals. This means that some unusual spikes (so long as it's less than 36 hours in a month) won't cause you to need a higher committed rate. For most people, this measurement method is beneficial since your spikes are thrown out. However, if you have sustained spikes,  this billing method can be painful .
texts.text: Long story short, this billing method measures your bandwidth on regular intervals and throws out the top 5% of your intervals. This means that some unusual spikes (so long as it's less than 36 hours in a month) won't cause you to need a higher committed rate. For most people, this measurement method is beneficial since your spikes are thrown out. However, if you have sustained spikes,  this billing method can be painful .

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Committed rate
texts.text: Committed rate

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you see a datacenter say something like "$15 per megabit", they're probably measuring with  committed rates . In this model, you choose a rate, like 10 megabits/second, and pay based on that rate. At $15 per megabit, your bandwidth charge would be $150 per month. The actual space in the rack and the power often costs extra.
texts.text: If you see a datacenter say something like "$15 per megabit", they're probably measuring with  committed rates . In this model, you choose a rate, like 10 megabits/second, and pay based on that rate. At $15 per megabit, your bandwidth charge would be $150 per month. The actual space in the rack and the power often costs extra.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Some people have good things to say about this billing method, but it seems awful to me. If you end up using 1 megabit per second, you still get billed for 10. If you have some spikes that creep over 10 megabit, even if you stay well under that rate as an average, the datacenter folks will ask you to do a higher commit. That means more money for something you may or may not use.
texts.text: Some people have good things to say about this billing method, but it seems awful to me. If you end up using 1 megabit per second, you still get billed for 10. If you have some spikes that creep over 10 megabit, even if you stay well under that rate as an average, the datacenter folks will ask you to do a higher commit. That means more money for something you may or may not use.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In my experience, this is is a  serious red flag . This suggests that the datacenter network probably doesn't have much extra capacity available within the datacenter, with its providers, or both. You sometimes see this in cities where bandwidth is more expensive. If you find a datacenter that's totally perfect, but they want to do a committed rate, ask if there's an option for 95th percentile. If not, I strongly suggest looking elsewhere.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Total bandwidth
texts.text: Total bandwidth

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Total bandwidth billing is what you normally see from most dedicated server or VPS providers. They will promise a certain transfer allotment and a network port speed. You will often see something like "10TB on a 100mbps port" and that means you can transfer 10TB in a month at at 100 megabits per second. They often don't care how you consume the bandwidth, but if you pass 10TB, you will likely pay overages per gigabyte. (Be sure to ask about the overage price.)
texts.text: Total bandwidth billing is what you normally see from most dedicated server or VPS providers. They will promise a certain transfer allotment and a network port speed. You will often see something like "10TB on a 100mbps port" and that means you can transfer 10TB in a month at at 100 megabits per second. They often don't care how you consume the bandwidth, but if you pass 10TB, you will likely pay overages per gigabyte. (Be sure to ask about the overage price.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This method is nice because you can watch it like a water meter. You can take your daily transfer, multiply by 30, and see if the transfer allotment is enough. Most datacenters will allow you to upgrade to a gigabit port for a fee and this will allow you to handle spikes a little easier.
texts.text: This method is nice because you can watch it like a water meter. You can take your daily transfer, multiply by 30, and see if the transfer allotment is enough. Most datacenters will allow you to upgrade to a gigabit port for a fee and this will allow you to handle spikes a little easier.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: For personal colocation, this bandwidth billing method is great. It could be a red flag for larger customers because it gives a hint that the datacenter might be oversubscribed on networking. If every customer wanted to burst to 100 megabit at the same time, there probably isn't enough network connectivity to allow everyone to get that guaranteed rate.

If every customer wanted to burst to 100 megabit at the same time, there probably isn't enough network connectivity to allow everyone to get that guaranteed rate.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Bring your own
texts.text: Bring your own

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Finally, you could always negotiate with bandwidth providers and bring your own bandwidth. This comes with its own challenges and it's probably not worth it for a personal colocation environment. Larger business like this method because they often have rates negotiated with providers for their office connectivity and they can often get a good rate within the colocation datacenter.
texts.text: Finally, you could always negotiate with bandwidth providers and bring your own bandwidth. This comes with its own challenges and it's probably not worth it for a personal colocation environment. Larger business like this method because they often have rates negotiated with providers for their office connectivity and they can often get a good rate within the colocation datacenter.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There are plenty of up-front costs with bringing your own bandwidth provider. Some of those costs may come from the datacenter itself, especially if new cabling is required.
texts.text: There are plenty of up-front costs with bringing your own bandwidth provider. Some of those costs may come from the datacenter itself, especially if new cabling is required.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Step 4: Plan for failure
texts.text: Step 4: Plan for failure

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Ensure that spare parts are available at a moment's notice if something goes wrong. In my case, I keep two extra hard drives in the rack with my servers as well as two sticks of RAM. My colocation datacenter is about four hours away by car, and I certainly don't want to make an emergency trip there to replace a broken hard drive.
texts.text: Ensure that spare parts are available at a moment's notice if something goes wrong. In my case, I keep two extra hard drives in the rack with my servers as well as two sticks of RAM. My colocation datacenter is about four hours away by car, and I certainly don't want to make an emergency trip there to replace a broken hard drive.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Buying servers with out of band management can be a huge help during an emergency. Getting console access remotely can shave plenty of time off of an outage. The majority of Supermicro servers come with an out of band management controller by default. You can use simple IPMI commands to reboot the server or use the iKVM interface to interact with the console. Many of these management controllers allow you to mount USB drives remotely and re-image a server at any time.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Ask the datacenter if they have a network KVM that you could use or rent during an emergency. Be sure to ask about pricing and the time expectations when you request one to be connected to your servers.
texts.text: Ask the datacenter if they have a network KVM that you could use or rent during an emergency. Be sure to ask about pricing and the time expectations when you request one to be connected to your servers.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Step 5: Contracts and payment
texts.text: Step 5: Contracts and payment

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Be sure to read the contract carefully. Pay special attention to how the datacenter handles outages and how you can request SLA credits. Take time to review any sections on what rights you have when they don't hold up their end of the deal.
texts.text: Be sure to read the contract carefully. Pay special attention to how the datacenter handles outages and how you can request SLA credits. Take time to review any sections on what rights you have when they don't hold up their end of the deal.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As with any contract, find out what happens when the contract ends. Does it auto-renew? Do you keep the same rates? Can you go month to month? Reviewing these sections before signing could save a lot of money later.
texts.text: As with any contract, find out what happens when the contract ends. Does it auto-renew? Do you keep the same rates? Can you go month to month? Reviewing these sections before signing could save a lot of money later.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Wrapping up
texts.text: Wrapping up

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Although cloud hosting has certainly made it easier to serve applications, there are still some people out there that prefer to have more customization than cloud hosting allows. For some applications, cloud hosting can be prohibitively expensive. Some applications don't tolerate a shared platform and the noisy neighbor issues that come with it.
texts.text: Although cloud hosting has certainly made it easier to serve applications, there are still some people out there that prefer to have more customization than cloud hosting allows. For some applications, cloud hosting can be prohibitively expensive. Some applications don't tolerate a shared platform and the noisy neighbor issues that come with it.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Colocation can be a challenging, but rewarding, experience. As with anything, you must do your homework. I certainly hope this post helps make that homework a little easier.
